headline: English Toffee
description: This recipe for English toffee is such a great gift idea around the holidays! Who wouldn't appreciate a box of nutty, chocolaty toffee under their tree?
name: English Toffee

recipeInstructions.text: Melt butter in a heavy skillet over medium heat. Stir in sugar and water, then bring to a boil. Add almonds and cook, stirring constantly, until nuts are toasted and sugar is golden. Pour mixture into the prepared pan; do not spread.
Immediately sprinkle chocolate chips onto hot sugar mixture. Spread chocolate over the surface as it melts. Let cool completely before breaking into pieces.

review.reviewBody: This was one of my first attempts at candy making. It didn't set up properly and I later found out that it needs to be brought to 300 degrees in order for it to harden properly.
Doesn't look like the picture but still tasty! The recipe calls for the almonds to be toasted with the sugar and butter so it becomes a part of the toffee layer rather than sprinkled on top.
Very simple recipe, easy to follow , will definitely use again!
AMAZING! I added 3Tbsp each of corn syrup and water after reading the reviews. Did not stir at all after the mixture came to a boil, and it turned out perfect!!
You might want to add that sugar mixture needs to cook to 300 degrees F and then proceed! Tried your way 3 times and failed! Not impressed!

Excellent. The texture was absolutely perfect with a nice snap that didn’t break your teeth, and very buttery. 
It took almost an hour on medium low to get the syrup up to hard crack, but it was well worth it.

I LOVE this recipe. I make this toffee and add it to a good chocolate chip cookie recipe and it makes bakery style cookies! I have also made this and added it to a brownie trifle and it is delicious! Highly recommend this easy recipe that is versatile for other uses!
It was great
It split the first time. In my years never had that happen. Made again and it is perfect.
Wonderful! Cooked slowly to 310 degrees and topped with mini chocolate chips!
I added 1 tbsp corn syrup and cooked it on high for 6 minutes stirring occasionally to keep the bottom from burning. It turned out great!

This is something my mother made every Christmas. I had never made it myself but took a chance and tried it. Turned out perfectly! I only had unsalted butter so I added salt while melting the butter, otherwise I followed it exactly and it turned out perfectly. Thank you for making my Christmas special.
I love this recipe! I've tried other Toffee recipes, this is my go-to!
Great Christmas Treat ! Kids ate up first batch, I had to make it twice to have ready for Christmas Day
I didn’t have a heavy enough pan. The butter separated from the sugar. I will have to try again.
Love the recipe! Butter and the pan make a huge difference. Not margarine. My mom always had the same pan ( which I inherited) it's a heavy club pan. Don't use a Teflon pan.
So good! Everyone loved it!
This turned out perfect!
perfect if you add a little corn syrup & salt as well as the water then vanilla once you take it off the heat

It was very thick, almost a challenge to bite into. The recipe says not to spread on the baking sheet. Next time I make this, I will warm my cookie sheet allowing the toffee to spread thinner. The taste is FABULOUS, I covered the melted milk chocolate with chopped walnuts.
Very easy to make and tastes delicious! Next time will use a little more almonds and some extra almonds for chocolate topping.

This was by far the easiest candy I have ever made. I didn't give it 5 stars simple because it did not tell me what temperature to cook the sugar mixture to but I looked at a similar recipe and found 285 was the magic number.

Didn't turn out right for me. Looks like just butter. I even added extra almonds because the edges weren't quite filled out with almonds. It tastes more like what it is: butter, sugar, chocolate, nuts; and not what I expected it to taste like (toffee).

It never got brown, like a paper bag! Mine came out a sort of tan! But I put Cashews in mine cause I can't chew Almonds! It tastes more like nut brittle! I don't really care how it looks cause it really tastes good! Thank you for sharing your recipe! Later Gator

Every Christmas I make this toffee and I double it! I follow Mommy from Seattle's tips and it turns out perfectly! Sometimes its hard to find slivered almonds but you can find them at a natural foods store. I love this recipe for gift giving along with almond biscotti. DONT change a thing!
very easy to made turned out wonderful everyone loved it.
Hardest thing was standing up to stir. Lol. Next hardest thing was not eating it all.

I read the reviews and one of them said to cook this low and slow, however that ended up in a disaster of burnt toffee before I was able to reach 300 degrees. Determined to try again, I went back to the original recipe and kept my heat on medium. I cooked it in a nonstick pan, and I added the two tablespoons of corn syrup as suggested in other reviews. As it got towards the end, I put my candy thermometer in and watched as it closely approached 300 degrees. I pulled it off and immediately spread Ghirardelli milk chocolate chips and some lightly salted, roasted, Dimond almonds that I had chopped finely. This time the result was superb and I will definitely make this again!
Very granulated and sugary! Will never attempt this particular recipe again. Go old school and make sure the concoction is 'old school', hard ball stage. What a waste of real butter!
You can’t post a candy recipe without telling people what temperature to cook the mixture to.

I melted the chocolate and aded it immediately after pouring the toffee into the baking tray. It didn't go well. Instead of layering on top of the toffee, I ended up with a toffee and chocolate swirl. Next time, I will either add solid chocolate chips on top of the toffee as the directions say, or let the toffee harden a little before pouring the chocolate. But it's still delicious!

Butter separated, may have cooked too long but did not turn color. All fresh ingredients 
 Had to throw away.
I'm looking forward to making this toffee again. It was the best toffee that I have ever had
Followed recipe as is and candy came out fine. Well I didn't put chocolate on top because I'm not a fan of chocolate. The toffee came out perfect.

Super easy and delicious. I made it in a non-stick pan and didn't have any trouble with it being oily. I followed the recipe exactly and it worked great. I just kind of took a guess on how "golden" the sugar was to get. It probably could have gone slightly longer to get more of a caramel flavour but I was worried about burning it and forgot to grab my thermometer. It came out with the correct consistency and broke apart nicely.

I have made this recipe in the past and it has turned out beautiful. I have always put in the almonds at the very end, say about 30 seconds before the temp reaches 300, (which should be included in the recipe for those that do not know the hard crack temp). This time I added the almonds about half way through and as I suspected, they burned. Also I had the separation issue but it was still cooking and it eventually came together before the hard crack stage. But I really suggest adding in your almonds near the end of the cooking process to prevent scorching or burning. It's still edible, but just has a slightly burned/scorched taste.

This is THE BEST toffee and so easy to make. I've even doubled it because we wanted more the second time! I'd suggest adding twice as many almonds and add some to the chocolate after it's been spread. 
Also, it takes about 30 minutes to melt the sugar, butter and almonds to the desired color. Muscle up because your arm does get a workout! That's fine though; this recipe is an unbelievable crowd pleaser!
P.S. This is the first time I've ever rated a recipe!
Easy recipes as long as you cook it long enough. Yummy

This is the first time I’ve made English toffee without corn syrup and it makes a huge difference. The butter just separates from the candy mixture. Very odd. Plus it bubbles and splatters a ton and I got burns from it.

Ok here’s how it’s really done! Double the ingredients! Cook to 285 deg, constantly storing with a wooden spoon! add the nuts of your choice! I used chopped walnuts and pecans, and a 1/2 tsp almond extract, constantly stir until you reach 295 deg then pour into your buttered pan, let cool for a few min then top with a mixture of milk chocolate chips and semi sweet chocolate chips, cover with foil until chips are soft enough to spread, then top with more nuts if you desire. Turns out fabulous!
Very good recipee....I add a little corn syrup and water because was sujested....becareful not to stir once starts boiling or will come out grainy
Came out great, 30 minutes to make. I was asked to make one gluten free dessert - it’s perfect
this is super easy! and everyone loves it...especially if you love Heath bars!
Did everything as slowly as possible and still separated. Wouldn't make again
Loved this recipe. Simple and delicious. I throw mine in the freezer (pan and all) to cool it faster. So good!!

THE BEST! These was addicting delicious. I used a non stick pot to cook the butter/sugar and found a couple things important to remember. 1. Use a whisk - I was using a nonstick pot so I used a silicone whisk a- it helps to keep the butter and sugar mixed together and slow it from cracking into an oily mess. Also constantly whisk/stir - it keep everything incorporated. 2. Let the toffee cool somewhat before adding the chocolate to the top. You don't need to wait long - 2 minutes is plenty. Just long enough that it isn't molten lava. Waiting for it to slightly set means you have chocolate on TOP of your toffee instead of inside it. 3. Play with your toppings. Keep the chocolate but while the chocolate is still melted - you can add toasted nuts (always toasted if not you are doing it wrong), sea salt, crushed pretzels, (I even saw someone add rosemary and sea salt). I used this as a cookie swap "cookie" and everyone asks me to bring it year after year. Easy and delicious!

This turns out great but the instructions are not really complete. That's the only reason I gave it a 4 star rating instead of a 5. You need to use a candy thermometer and it needs to reach between 310 and 315 degrees to make sure that the texture is correct. Also it takes longer than 15 minutes to reach that point.

I've made this toffee recipe many, many times. Sometimes the butter separates a little at the end, but I just drain it off and it still tastes great. I followed it to a T this time (with the exception of doubling it and adding nuts to top instead of in batch), and it still separates at the end. (Maybe my candy thermometer is a little off? Or maybe I should use less butter if doubling...not sure). Anyway I was going to give this a 4 star but I've made it every Christmas season for the past six years since I found the recipe, so I think that deserves 5 stars because it must be doing something right.
Very easy to make a little to sweet for me but it is Toffee...

I have now made 12+ batches of this recipe. Of them, it only turned out for me 2 times. The other times it separated. I have read ALL the reviews, I have tried ALL the different measurements, also the tricks for trying to get the toffee to reincorporate. I have tried on clear days, dry days, and various other weather types. And nothing is working. I don’t usually struggle with cooking or baking, but for whatever reason, this recipe is not working for me. I’m done and searching for a new one. Good luck to everyone else, and if someone has an idea that is not already listed here, I’d be open to learning.
Great Toffee! I get requests for this recipe all the time and requests to bring it to functions.
Loved it! Only change I made was before pouring it out to cool I added 1tsp of vanilla, other than that delicious

This is a good recipe for a butter toffee. I don't finish it the way the recipe suggest with chocolate and almonds. I usually mix in peanuts or whatever other nut variety I'm in the mood for. This makes a great candy.

This is a 5-star recipe with 3-star instructions which leads to a lot of 1-star reviews. Here’s the key missing element: it’s not humidity, it’s how hot you get the mixture – it must get over 300F, close to burning. Here are a few more helps: First, stir and keep stirring to the end. Second, one clue that you are close to done you will smell a slight wisp of the mixture burning. I typically keep going for a minute after that and then quickly put it into my buttered Pyrex dish. Third, as you cook the butter/sugar mixture once it gets boiling the appearance will change twice. At first it doesn't seem to be mixed, the butter floats on top, and it changes to be kind of a silvery shimmery mixture that clings to the side of the pot. That mixture will then change turning medium brown, look a little greasy, and not cling to the side of the pot so much as you stir it. When that starts you are close to being done. Stir for a minute of two more unless you smell it burning. I hope this helps you.
I've made this now 4 times and I (and the recipe) get (s) better each time! Toffee is life!

Excellent! I made this with the help of the last reviewer suggesting to melt butter sugar and water together along with that extra tbsp of water and the light corn syrup. Definitely a must so there's no sugar residue remaining. Needed to make another batch because after posting this on fb my neighbor wanted it - all of it Lol. This is so easy and quick :) a fool proof recipe that totally melts in your mouth-AaaaMazing!

This is a pretty good basic recipe. I like my toffee more buttery so I use equal parts butter and sugar. You will also want to use more water (I use 1/4 cup to 1 cup sugar) so that the the toffee hardens more slowly. I make toffee every Christmas and it is ALWAYS damp where I live, so I thought I'd share some tips: 1) Always make sure toffee is a full 310 degrees (hard crack stage) before pouring! 300 is OK in dry weather, but go hotter if it's damp. Otherwise it will be gummy. 2) in damp weather, transfer to the fridge to set as soon as you can. The toffee will "sweat" a bit so Blot it with a paper towel once it's hardened. 3) store in air-right containers, preferably in the fridge.

1 c sugar, 1 c butter, 1/4 c water, pinch of salt and about 1/2 tsp vanilla once cooked. I made 4 batches today, using various nuts in each. Very good and easy. Kept heat (on gas cook top) between medium and medium low using an iron skillet. It took about 15 minutes, stirring frequently. Poured in a lined 9 X 13 pan, patted some nuts in, sprinkled with chocolate chips, spread once melted and topped with more nuts, again pressing nuts into chocolate. Once the color becomes brown it will thicken like a roux. That is when I took it off heat. Will make this again very soon. Also I used more nuts than called for.

My mom used to make this recipe every Christmas. It took me a few attempts to get the hang of it, but this recipe is perfect. The trick is to keep your heat LOW and use a good stainless steel pan. This way you don't have to stir as much and that will keep the sugar and the butter from separating. You should only have to stir toward the end every few minutes or so. Do not stir constantly. Don't worry it won't burn. Just let it do it's thing.

I used a cast iron pan, stirred constantly but it turned into a sugary crumbly mess. Maybe I should have cooked longer. I noticed at around 280 deg that the texture changed. Not sure I will try again unless I have more information.

It's a wonderful recipe. Took several attemps to get it just perfect, but even the first versions were really good.
Worked best for me adding the water and corn syrup and salt. Covered it with chocolate chips and pecans.
This was amazing!

Love this recipe! I melted the butter, added the sugar, water and the almonds stirring constantly on low heat. I set my thermometer to alert me once the temp hit 300 degrees then I added a little vanilla and some sea salt before pouring it into a jelly roll that I had sprayed with cooking spray and lined with parchment paper. Pure perfection!

I was so anxious to try this recipe that I used pecans instead of almonds. (I had them already,) and it was phenomenal. I assumed it would be more difficult than fudge or pralines, but it was even easier!

It wasn't raining, but the humidity outside was at 75% when I made it. (Thanks, New Orleans.) I cooked it to 310 degrees, and it was perfect. I did it again today just to be sure it wasn't a fluke, and it came out brilliantly once again. 

This is definitely going on my holiday favorites list!
Mine turned out oily. I followed the directions carefully, cooked slowly, and the humidity outside is only 30%. I don't know what else I could have done.
Oh. .. this was awesome! I love English Toffee but never knew it was this easy to make. Great recipe... will definitely make it again.

This is similar to the toffee I've made each Christmas for friends and family since the '80s. I use 1 lb of good quality butter, 2C sugar, a small bag of slivered almonds and 1 'giant' Hershey bar for each batch. That's it - no water. Cook butter/sugar at medium low in a heavy pan (I use the pan of my pressure cooker). Cook til it almost reaches hard crack stage and then add all almonds, let cook til hard crack and then pour quickly onto large piece of aluminum foil (I spread it on my kitchen table and put a towel under it). Spread as thinly as possible as it will harden as you're spreading. (My end result is thinner than the picture shown.)Break chocolate bar into pieces, let it sit a few minutes and then spread over the hardened candy. I let it sit overnight and then break into pieces and store in tins. Tips: only use high quality, brand name butter and let it soften first at room temp. Stir occasionally at first and then as it starts to change consistency and especially as it starts to change color, stir constantly, using a wooden spoon. I don't have a candy thermometer but determine its readiness by 1) color (coffee with moderate amount of cream) AND 2) stream a bit of the toffee from the pan into a cup of ice water - if it makes a brittle piece of candy instantly, it's ready. Don't put almonds in too early as they will burn. Re butter separating, I've had that happen a couple of times but I just stirred briskly as I was pouring onto foil to incorporate.

Super yummy!! After many trial and error I found that a cast iron skillet was the golden ticket. I do t care what other recipes say, only stir every 3-5 minutes NOT continuously! My butter didn't seperates when I backed off on stirring!!! Didn't use a thrmometer but waited to get the caramel color and it was perfect! I used dark chocolate on the top....heaven!

Great recipe, I made this to give away to family for Christmas and it got rave reviews. I'm now getting email requests for the recipe. The only thing I noticed was it took longer than 5-6 minutes for the toffee to turn to the right color but the extra time was well worth the wait. This will become one of the "must" make on my list. Thanks for sharing the recipe.... Liza
I thought I cooked it wrong because all the butter looked like it separated but it came out great. I used Hershey bars on top instead of chocolate chips...melted easier.

My recipe calls for 1 lb. butter, 2 1/2 cups sugar, 2 cups whole almonds (melt butter, add sugar and cook over medium heat until sugar melts and mix is foamy, then add almonds). Stir until almonds pop and mixture begins to SMOKE! Pour into jelly roll pan. Cool slightly. Cover with 11-16 oz. semi-sweet chocolate chips. Sprinkle with chopped nuts. Cool completely then break into pieces.

After reading the reviews and messing up the first batch the second time around it turned out WONDERFUL. I used the ingredients that the recipe calls for but I did use a candy thermometer. There is no way that this recipe takes only 15 minutes. It was more like an hour because the mixture has to heat slowy and until it reaches 310.

I made this and followed direction as written. The only thing is that it really takes longer than 20 minutes to make. It took me 30 to get the right boil on the syrup. Remember when making this type of candy low and slow is the way you will want to bring the syrup up to tempature.

This did not work for me. I tried it twice and both times the toffee never turned brown and the mixture separated to make a gooey mess. I too wonder about the amount of butter since it all rose to the top of the pan while cooking.
I made this last night and everyone who tasted it begged for more. This recipe is a keeper, I made no chages to it and it came out fantastic.

I am not a sweet tooth, but toffee is a serious weakness. For that reason, I'd always left it to the professionals and bought mine from a bona fide candy maker wanting only the 'good stuff'. Until last week. On a whim, I decided to venture forth and chose this recipe based on ease and reviews--it did not disappoint. Turned out perfectly!! Friends and family loved it as did I. I will be making it again for bake sales and holidays for years to come.

First time making toffee. This was easy and turned out great. I didn't have almonds but had pistacios. Used them, chopped in the toffee and on top after I put the white and milk chocolare chips on and spread. See many variations you could do and will next time. I did what the recipe said to do as far as the instructions. Next time I thnk I will try the no stir method as some of the reviews suggested.

This recipe is really easy & very delicious! I used Ritz instead of Saltines. I had a very difficult time getting it off the cookie sheet. I would try greasing it more next time. Delicious, but not very presentable..
Safe to say I butchered this one badly
unbelievably yum!

Tried this recipe today for Christmas. Read the reviews and followed the recommendations others made. My batch came out oily, separated from the chocolate when it chilled and I cut it, and had a ton of butter pushed off to the side of the pan. I'm going to try the corn syrup next time and see if that corrects the problem.

Fantastic recipe AS IS. I can't stress enough that you use the exact amount of butter the recipe calls for, no less. If you use less, you are ruining the product. The trick is cooking temperature!! Got to stay on top of the temp and using cast iron is a toffee tradition for a reason, because it works.
I followed the recipe exactly - even while it was raining cats and dogs outside - and it was perfect! I didn't use a non-stick pan because I noticed that even on fudge,that's not a great ideal.

I have been making this same recipe for almost 40 years now, but I use Hershey's chocolate bars (it takes about 7 for a long glass casserole dish). The bars melt in seconds, and you just spread the melted milk chocolate to cover the toffee. It is very easy, but you must stir the butter and sugar constantly to prevent burning.

I have made English Toffee many times before, but thought I would give a different recipe a try. BIG mistake! While this recipe was edible, it did not taste like the English Toffee I know and love. After the sugar hardened, there was a lot of oily substance in the pan, I suspect from all the butter. It didn't turn out like something you could hand out without napkins or package up and give as gifts because it was way too greasy, and frankly, didn't taste all that much like English Toffee. I was disappointed.

I just tried this recipe. It's great just the way it is. I did use a candy thermometer like was suggested and cooked to 300 degrees. I made 2 batches. One with walnuts and one with almonds. Both were great

This recipe turns out well, but I added 2 teaspoons of Mexican vanilla and a little less water. I use a big cast iron skillet and I doubled the recipe. I stir constantly with a flat spatula. I don't use a candy thermometer, I just go by color. I like it with salted butter. A 12 oz package of mini semi sweet chocolate chips melts fast and spreads smoothly. Chopped toasted almonds sprinkled over all. People I share this with think I'm a kitchen genius. I live in a humid place and don't have trouble with candy behavior. So delicious!

This is a delicious recipe for English toffee!! This was my first time attempting to make toffee, so I was very nervous about making it. My niece and I tried it, and the first batch burnt. It was because I got nervous because the sugar wasn't melting at first, and I think I turned the fire up too high. Well, after tossing that batch, we tried it again, this time with the fire kept very low,allowing the sugar to melt slowly and stirring every few minutes. We used raw almonds and roasted them in the oven separately. While the sugar was melting, we let the almonds cool. Once they were cool, I rough chopped them. I didn't add the almonds to the toffee until right before I poured it onto the cookie sheet. It turned out wonderful!! I was soooo proud and happy we tried it again. I will definitely be making this treat for the holidays.
excellent recipe!!!

I love this recipe, it is simple and I usually have the ingredients around the house already. I have made it with and without out the almonds, you really can't tell the difference. I have also added a pinch of salt to bring out the flavor a little more.This toffee is especially good when dipped in white chocolate.
This recipe is a keeper for sure!

We cooked it for longer than stated, though I did double the reciepe. Cooked until it was golden and smelled like toffe, and tested a drop in cold water. Melt in your mouth, easy, I omitted the nuts because of allergy so I literally had all the ingredients without going to the store....gotta love that!

Second time around for me with this recipe. The first time it separated and I hadn't read the reviews to know there is a remedy for this. drained off the top and the bottom stuff made good toffee. I just finished my second batch. First I calibrated my candy thermometer, it was about 15 degrees low, ok. Took it slow and easy. I started getting concerned when it began to boil, I thought the froth on top was coming over and got another pan ready, not needed. Finally it began to turn color about 225 degrees. Thermometer 15 degrees low? finally about 235 I felt it would be burning if I didn't get it out of there. I had a cup of ice water with me to test it, and it was granulated. Well, I am forging ahead, I may have to try it again. I had to laugh at some of the superstitions, like stirring it only clockwise and only making it in dry humidity. I live in Colorado, 20% is a humid day here.

I've made this recipe several times. it is perfect every time. one of the keys is to cook this until it is hard candy. i've been making candy for years from old recipes - some handed down from family. i was taught to test the candy in a cup of cold water. this means when you think the candy is done down a bit of it into cold water. when it is crunchy in the cold water you know it is done for toffee. this IS just at that point where the color of the candy/caramel changes and starts to darken. pull it of NOW. : ) i pour this into a rectangle cake pan lined with parchment paper. then i add whole roasted almonds - a few scattered and pushed in so that they are inside the toffee. : ) then i do put the chocolate chips on top while it is hot. this works perfectly. a few minutes later the chips are melted and i use a spatula to spread the chocolate over all of the toffee. after this i quickly sprinkle chunks and ground up roasted almonds. i put the almonds in the food processor and pulse so there are some big chunks and some small and some crushed. wala!!! perfecto!

ok I just wasted 2 batches of ingredients on this. I made it last year and it came out great! Maybe I used a different pan or something, but I poured off 1/2 cup of butter before pouring the second batch out and the result was still swimming in a lagoon of oil. Oh well, I'll see how it turns out, but I think it's easier to go buy english toffee in the nice candy shop in town next year and save myself the grief, the mess and waste of time and money. Congrats, to those who have succeded, it probably was something I did wrong as I have made this last year and it was GREAT!

I gave it one star so it's easy to find help when people have problems making it. It's not greasy! If you are saying your toffee is "greasy" that means it SEPARATED! I have read that when it does that, you can add 1 TABLESPOON of HOT water at a time (no more than 5 of them) until the mixture comes back together. DO NOT make toffee when it is raining or snowing. You will not get crunchy candy. You will get chewy candy that sticks to your teeth. Use BUTTER (not margarine, crisco, etc.). Don't cook it too fast. Goes from done to burnt in a few seconds (as fast as it takes to count 4 mississippis!). Hope that helps. Also, use a deep pot. If you don't, the mix will bubble up and over the pot while cooking. Candy is very tricky, and can still separate for reasons nobody knows.

As a first time Toffee maker, I was a little nervous however this recipe couldn't have made an easier and more wonderful batch of candy. A couple things I changed per reviews were replacing 2 Tbs of butter with corn syrup to prevent sugar crystallization and I followed the instructions to melt the butter then keep it on the lower side of medium for the rest of the time giving the butter time to incorporate with the sugar. Also, I used Parchment Paper instead of buttering the large cookie sheet which worked perfectly. The only change I'll make next time is a touch of vanilla. I did use a candy thermometer watching it rise to 310 before pulling off the burner which resulted in a perfect crunch with zero burn issues.

This was an easy recipe however, I was dissatisfied with the turnout...had to toss it out..made another batch and it turned out like the 1st batch..was so dissapointed that I had to run back to the store and make something else for the Holidays...

I've made this twice, following the exact recipe. Very easy and delicious outcome! The outcome really varied on the length of cooking time. The darker the colour of the mixture, the more crunchy it will be. The first time I made it it wasn't as crunchy, but it was just as delicious! I took it to my tennis lessons and they were a hit. I haven't done them with almonds yet, but when I do, I'm sure that it will be just as delicious!

I don't have a candy thermometer so I stirred on medium all through the buttery, sticky dough looking bubbles until it started to turn to a toffee color with few bubbles. Probably 15 minutes of stiring. Then I chilled mine in the fridge after to harden it enough to break apart. I don't think I'll add the nuts to the mix next time to make it easier to cut.
